@newmumonline as the stepfather of two boys, I know “rough and tumble” isn’t necessarily symptomatic of a toxic male, but as someone who was teased and physically beaten as a kid, I know it can be. The kid in the commercial on the bottom of the “rough and tumble” was not smiling when the man pulled that other kid off him. Maybe the commercial wasn’t talking to your  kid, but there are definitely kids out there who need to hear the message, from this commercial, from people who have seen the commercial, and from people who have never seen or heard of this commercial. The ad is not perfect, it’s clunky, but I do not care, I support the message that there is a lot of male behavior in the world that needs to be checked, and it’s men’s responsibility to check ourselves and each other.

@bagel.bitchhh @cream_doughnut First off, can we address the claims about “toxic masculinity” around here? “Toxic masculinity” was a concept invented by 20th-century upper-class gentlemen and used by feminists to undermine authority. This concept ‘created’ a phenomenon to challenge stereotypes, by using stereotypes. From your comments what I have gleaned is that 
1) If men don’t publicly denounce this concept they are toxic, sexist beings
2) If I disagree with their message there must be something wrong with me (or those that think like me) 
3) “Toxic masculinity” is something that only men can ‘produce’ 
At best, this merely plays on gender stereotypes that only  men are aggressive and vulgar. Something which would be sexist, if you were not occupied in the double standard that men are inherently aggressive. Your comments have shown that you are perfectly willing to engage in reverse sexism, because you perceive that men are the aggressors. 
The ad, and this post, seems to blame men and masculinity for bullying and torment, which is moral relativism at its finest. Did you know that almost two-thirds of women bullied in the workplace were also bullied by women? That’s from a survey taken by Cecilia Harvey from the  Development and Learning in Organisations journal. That’s not taking into account school bullying, where authorities don’t have an exact figure of which gender bullies others more. 
And before you say that the bullying by men is more hurtful, that’s impossible to quantify, considering that victims may feel less or more hurt depending on circumstances. Bear in mind that boys can also be involved in ‘girl-type’ bullying and that girls can also use violence & extortion against other kids.
